WRITING.TITLE: Spoilers Below! Lore Discussion!
WRITING.TEXT: This could maybe go into the Sunless Skies forum, but the story of Skies seems to be moving away from the Neath, and a lot of the lore I'm talking about originally came from FL, soooo..... And seriously, lots of spoilers. I'll censor out what I can, but not all of it because then this would just be a big white block. A lot of people talk about the sixth city. It's been hinted at that gt;!Paris will be the sixth city! lt;, but it is definitely not something set in stone. Some people argue that gt;!there will never be a sixth city! lt; for a number of reasons. One being that gt;!Mr. Wines is the only master who still believes in the Bazaar's mission, and some masters are even trying to actively sabotage it! lt; and that gt;!since France saw the devastation brought onto the British Empire from their deal with the Bazaar they would likely be unlikely to ever make a deal of their own! lt; Okay, I think that's most of the spoilers I will be covering, so I'm not going to censor anymore. I'm on mobile, and I'm not even sure if it's working anyway. You've been warned. For the sake of this discussion, I want to assume that the Masters put aside their differences and decide they want another city, and decide that they want that city to be Paris; I'm wondering what they would offer France in exchange for Paris. One theory I have is that after The Empress lead the exodus to the High Wilderness, presumably leaving London mostly abandoned, the Masters would start doing some city shopping. This would place the time period as the Dawn of the 20th century. As I said above, France would have to be extremely desperate before making any deals with the masters after they saw how it blew up in Britain's face. They would have to certain that the collapse of their entire empire would be worth whatever they'd gain. I believe the time period is the most important thing here. At the Dawn of the 20th century, France was working on making alliances with nearby nations, but they were heavily divided internally. Of course, who knows what the state of France was in the fallen london universe given that the disappearance of one of the other major works powers probably influenced history in all sort of ways. Either way, nothing particularly big is happening in France for the first decade or so. At least no major disasters that would warrant selling the entire city to fix. This could change however in 1914 which is when the first world war began. It would be hard to say if the first world War would even happen in this universe, the biggest problem being that Germany has not been formed and is still Prussia. (At least I think so? This is from the Empress' Shadow story and I never bought that one). I still think the war would happen despite this, the arch-duke Ferdinand would still be assassinated which would cause both Russia and France to move to war, and I find it likely that even if Germany is not fully formed at this time they would likely still have their alliance with Austria-Hungary so Prussia would still attack France. France suffered a lot during the first world War, but during the war as we knew it they had Britain helping them out. In the fallen london universe; however, they would be left alone to fight Prussia while Russia slowly gathered their troops before even having a chance to invade Prussia, let alone give France any support. I think in this universe, France would be absolutely devastated by Prussia and this would put them in a very desperate situation. I can definitely see the Masters try to capitalize off of that. I would hope that the French would learn from the forth city and not just wish for their city to be protected from their enemies because that would be boring to have a trade we've already seen. Really though, the deal itself can be a lot of things, but this is what I've pictured. Prussian soldiers are a few days from overtaking Paris. The French army is in shambles. Russia is still struggling to mobilize, so no help is coming from them. The French agree to give the Masters Paris if they could destroy all of Prussia and win the war for Paris. I can see a number of ways to do this; maybe the Bazaar uses correspondence to set Prussia ablaze, or maybe the Masters themselves fight against all of Prussia. Maybe they could even convince some devils to come to the surface to do all the fighting. Lots of options. Anyway, this was long.

Thank you for reminding me of all that! There's so much lore it can get a bit difficult to keep everything straight. :P I still want to go with WW1 being the catalyst in Paris being taken so I did a bit of research in who the Masters would see as the "Owner" of Paris at this time. The prime minster at the time was Georges Clemenceau (who was also nicknamed The Tiger, and the idea that the French equivalent to the Traitor Empress would be called The Tiger would be awesome). When it comes to something he loves that he would want from the Masters, I believe the best bet would actually be the Nation of France. Throughout his political career, Clemenceau advocated for France to be a powerful military force and to be prepared for any conflict. So I can see the deal he would make would either be to preserve the nation be loves or to give France military strength only possible in the Neath.

I didn't know that! Very interesting. It is a little sad that the reasoning for the deal was just to save another dying person. If we ever fully see the sixth city being taken I'd want it to be something unique. The first five cities were all unique in their circumstances, and that seems really similar to London's situation. I really like the idea I replied with to the previous comment.

Also, if the sixth city turns out to be Prussia maybe the shadow wouldn't even need to stage a coup. We never fully find out what happens to the Dawn Machine after the exodus to the high wilderness (at least, not that I know of) so it could still be in the Neath. If the leader of Prussia really likes learning about judgements he would probably be interested in studying the Dawn Machine. Either that or be disgusted by it, but the Bazaar promising the leader of Prussia a semi-judgement that he could personally communicate with would probably do the trick.

I would love to hear what you think when you have more time to better arrange your thoughts! The lore of the fallen london universe is so vast that you really need the ideas of other people to reach any sort of understanding. It feels like I discover something new about the lore everyday :D

I remember reading that! That always made me think that Paris does end up being the sixth city and they somehow also get through Avid Horizon. Though I suppose there could be other ways, or they just travel down to the Neath through the canal instead of taking the whole city with them.

WRITING.TITLE: I love Skies, but
WRITING.TEXT: I seriously love Skies more than Seas when it comes to game play. I couldn't really get into Seas with all the repetition and slower combat and travel that Skies for the most part did away with. However, I love the Neath. I find it so interesting from a storytelling perspective, and I feel like it just has so much more potential than the High Wilderness. I just hope an update to Skies has some sort of way for us to play in the Neath again. I find it unlikely as it feels that the story is shifting away from the Neath and the Bazaar, but I really miss how the Neath made me feel.

I was raised Mormon, and discovered a couple years ago that I was transgender. I agree with a pervious reply, you should develop a "logical family" before telling your actual family. It is likely you won't get a lot of support from your actual family, like you said, so you will need that support from somewhere. Also, you should practice coming out before telling your family. Tell friends, even those who are just online. You won't be able to do it perfectly, but practice will make it much easier. If you feel like this is likely to cause major issues then you might want to even wait until you have moved out of your home and are completely independent. Most parents are not cruel when in this situation, but you know your parents better than anyone so only you would know when the best time is.

WRITING.TITLE: My Story of Growing Up Mormon
WRITING.TEXT: This is going to be long, just so you've been warned. I'm also doing this on mobile so there may be some typos, but I'll try my best to catch them. I was raised Mormon. In the middle of Utah, actually. Very early in my life, my parents got divorced because my dad was cheating on my mother. It was unfortunate, but not the main point of my story. Sufficient to say, after that my mother began to push for our family to become active in the church since she was convinced that our inactivity is what lead to my father's actions. That happened when I was seven. Fast forward a year. Due to the sudden absence of my father's income, we moved even deeper into Mormon territory, Ogden if any of you are familiar. At eight years old I was first exposed to porn. Ironically, I only found it because a talk in church mentioned it offhand and, being the ever knowledge-seeking child I was, when I heard a word I'd had no understanding of I decided to type it into Google. You can guess the rest. I consumed porn regularly for a couple months before my mother found out. She sat me down while she was in tears and told me that what I'd done was one of the worst sins imaginable, and that I would need to tell the bishop what I'd done. That was awful. With everything that has happened lately, I'm luckily I wasn't assaulted, but my shame made me want to kill myself as I spoke to my bishop. Only eight, and already wanting to die. Fun. I was placed in Religious Therapy. While there I was placed with exclusively male therapists, and often asked turned describe the images I had seen in detail. Again, this happened while I was between the ages of 8-12. I desperately tried to talk to these therapists about my growing depression and self-loathing as well as the strain about my distrust of men in general(including the three therapists I went through), but no matter what problem I had their solution was always that I had to stop viewing porn. By middle school I refused to see any religious therapists. My mother tried a bit, but I refused to say a word to anyone who used religion in their therapy. I also moved wards a couple times, and each time I had to repeat the process of telling my new bishop about my sins. Despite being completely honest about everything, I was still given full priesthood authority. I was allowed to pass the sacrament when I turned twelve, and prepare it when I turned fourteen. When I was fifteen we moved to Wyoming, and with that came a lot of revelations. I discovered I was a transgender woman. This was because of a number of pieces of media I had begun to consume during our move that exposed be to the LGBTQ community. When I first discovered this, I nearly killed myself. I had a plan, and almost did myself in. All that stopped me was the fear that Hell was waiting for me, so I guess the church did something good for once. I kept this hidden for two years before I told anyone. I ended up telling some friends, and it was amazing. I also lost my virginity, an event that stressed me out to the point of developing an ulcer, and the stress from hiding this fact from my family lead to that relationship falling apart. A year after that my mother found out. She kicked me out of the house for the day so she could "think." That was the second time I nearly killed myself. I was left all alone for hours on end, and I had a plan, but I luckily survived. Now it's three years later. I got through seminary, though it was a nightmare. My mother refuses to acknowledge my gender change and dead names me daily. But, I'm saving up to leave the conservative town I live in to the west coast. So that's my one major hope now.
Young woman fights the Sun to cure her body dysphoria

As a trans woman, my favorite advice is to have your story include trans characters but don't have it tell the audience what it means to be a transgender person. Like, what it means to be trans is a story that should be told by a trans person. Unless you are trans, which I did assume by your phrasing but I could be wrong, then it wouldn't be your story to tell. A simpler way of putting this could be that you make it obvious that the character is trans but don't make the entire character's story be about their struggles because they are trans. Also, as side advice that I'm sure you already know, avoid really overused cliches. Like, "My name used to be Gabe but now I'm *dramatic hair flip* Gabriella" or the character disguising themselves as their dead gender to sneak into someplace. Thank you for asking how to do this! The fact that you are willing to research is already much better than some famous authors do.
I'd love for you to pm me, though I haven't had much time to do a lot of writing lately, so forgive me if it takes awhile for me to get back to you

WRITING.TITLE: I truly think that the church is collapsing, and I've never been so excited
WRITING.TEXT: I live in a small, Wyoming town that is mostly Mormon. For context, I'm a transgender woman so I spent most of my time in the church as part of the young men's group. I knew a lot about the young men in my quorum, and not a single one was worthy of using the sacrament, at least according to what the church believes. I'd seen those boys have sex with multiple young women, drink alcohol frequently, and some of them even did a collection of drugs. Despite this, they all performed their priesthood duties without a second thought. I checked in on my ward recently. There are no more young men. All the priesthood duties are being performed by the elders. All those boys I knew have gone inactive. A lot of the young women went with them. At least when it comes to my town, the church is being held up by the really old. It will probably only be a couple decades until they can't do all the priesthood ordinances by themselves, and a a handful more before they die off. I've never been more excited

From what I understand it is like most addictive substances. Alcohol for example. Alcohol is bad for you. Period. It hurts your body and is addictive. However, a lot of people use alcohol for social activities; and in moderation that can be fine. The same goes for porn. Aside from this, there are a lot of issues with the porn industry itself. Plenty of videos are recorded and published without consent, videos are stolen from the personal sites of some models and re-uploaded onto free sites, and some are even obtained using sex trafficking. When finding a site to support, I usually recommend finding a single model you like and supporting then directly rather than finding random videos that could have been obtained by less legal means. There are also studies showing that watching excess porn leads to twisting men's views of sex. Because of this, you should always be aware of what material you are viewing and how much of it. If you are in a relationship where you are sexually intimate with the other, you should be honest about your porn viewing habits, and it is a good recommendation to even integrate your intake of porn with your sexual activity with your partner. This makes the activity less of an individual behavior and more of a social one that increases your intimacy with one another. TL:DR - Porn, like most addictive substances, is harmful. However, like most addictive substances, carefully moderated consumption can reduce these risks.

I'm trans as well, nineteen right now, and as someone who did come out to my family I'm going to tell you that while it probably won't go horribly, it will not necessarily make you feel better. I came out to my mother three years ago. She has yet to even acknowledge it, pretending it's not even there. While this is definitely not the worst way she could have responded (at least she still let me stay in the house after I was eighteen), it does not feel good to be so invisible. What's more important at your age is to build yourself a new family who accepts who you are. Friends who can support you in case your family does not. Then, after you have a support group, come out to your family if you still feel like you need to. And who knows? They could be really chill and accepting. Just take your time

As a trans woman raised in the church, I can state that the church teaches that biological sex and gender are the same thing. I have even had it stated by a seminary teacher that was also a highly respected bishop, "When you go to heaven you will be the gender you were born with. So when certain people have surgeries to change this, they will have a little surprise waiting for them when they die." This was one of the main things that set me against the church, actually. According to Mormon doctrine I'd end up in the Telestial kingdom, which is stated to be "100 times better than life on earth." However, that can't possibly true if I am forced to be a gender I am not. TL:DR - The church is dumb and thinks that gender and sex are the same thing, and believe that if a trans person undergoes sex realignment surgery they will be reverted to their dead gender when they get to the afterlife.
Most Mormons think the trump presidency is a good thing. Although if I still believed in "the latter days" I would definitely think that was a sign of the times

I am a transgender woman, and I was raised in the church. Even before I realized that I was a woman, I suffered from intense self-loathing because of the church's strict divide between genders. I hated my young men's quorum, and much preferred spending time with the young women. I was forced by my family to attend the Boy Scouts, an activity that constantly reaffirmed the belief that I was wrong somehow. Due to this loathing and my lack of social connections, I became severely depressed. My mother noticed this, and arranged for me to see a counselor. Any other counselor could have probably realized that I was trans, but my mom decided to send me to a Mormon counselor. He did nothing but worsen my depression. I had developed a slight porn habit, and my counselor focused on this fact, blaming it for all of my troubles and making me feel even more shame. When I first discovered that I was trans I tried to kill myself that same day. The only exposure I had gotten relating to people changing their biological sex was brief mentions in church, and that info had always framed such people as crazy perverts who did so for sex. All the shame I had felt leading up to that moment came to a head, and I wanted to die. The only reason I didn't kill myself in that moment was out of fear that I would go to Hell because of what I was. If you're looking for positive influences the church has had on my life, that may be the only one. Over the next couple years I distanced myself from the church, and now I hate it vehemently for what it has put me though, and what it has put countless others through. The church has built a divide between my family and myself. My mother broke down into tears when she found out, and to this day a full year later she still believes that I am being lead astray. My younger sister and I used to have a great relationship, but once she found out she stopped speaking to me. She tells her friends at school how I am stupid and am making this all up for attention. TL;DR The church worsened my depression and self-loathing, nearly bringing me to killing myself, and formed an immense divide between me and my family

WRITING.TITLE: An Interesting Query
WRITING.TEXT: I'm a huge fan of speed running, especially when the game is not one that seems to lend itself to that format. An example of this would be a person speed running Sunless Sea, and hoping that the rng of that game twisted in your favor. So of course when I got into Fallen London, I started thinking about what it would be like to speed run this game. Of course, traditional speed running with a running timer would not be appropriate for this game. It would not be enjoyable to observe or perform as it would start with the player quickly using up their starting 20 actions, and then doing nothing for ten minutes at a time. It would also require the player to stay awake for potentially hundreds of hours, so that doesn't seem like a good way of doing things. A better way of "timing" runs in a game like this would be by counting the number of in-game actions it took you to accomplish any one achievement. This would allow runners to stop and take breaks, and even allow them to not use any actions until they get a particular opportunity card they may need. Proving the number of actions actually used is a difficult task, and the closest solution I could think of is by having the runner echo every action they make, and change the title to the number that action was (or numbers for choices that take more than one action). It is not a perfect solution, but doing this would require some level of mutual trust. As for categories, that's the fun part. You of course could have categories for all the ambitions, at least once they're all finished. You could have a category dedicated to obtaining Courier's footprint, or to obtain 7 in all the "A Name Scrawled/Whispered/Flourished/Written" categories. There are a lot of options there. Let me know if this sounds interesting to you, and if anyone else has ever done it before. I just might start making alts to start doing this.
That's awful. I didn't keep count, but I believe I was nearing the double digits when I finally got unlucky

I just find that idea so hilarious in the terms of the actual story of what's happening. Your character breaks out of New Newgate, and immediately begins a quest to destroy themselves and everything they hold dear

I would say that there should be a seperation between Fate-Assisted Runs and No Fate Runs. That way people who are willing to spend fate for certain stories can. Perhaps it can be divided even further into Free Fate-Assisted runs where you can use the fate you are given at the start but not any more. More on Fate, I personal think any fate-locked path that is purely for grinding(such as gaining favors through the items that increase renown, instantly curing menaces, and also buying more cards) should be banned. Fate locked storylines could be a way to gain special items that can be beneficial, but buying infinite cards or favors seems to artificially lower the action count. But if people really wanted to do that, they could just create yet another category On seasonal events, I believe that they should be divided into their own category as well. Perhaps a blanket rule that says if any action you perform is only possible during a seasonal event, then that run goes under the seasonal event category. That way a runner could still play while an event is active, but still be in the category that does not include those events. Also, happy cake day!

I really don't know. I personally see devils as a puppet that is finely tailored to seduce and tempt each individual person. Perhaps, deep down, they have their own personal preferences such as what opera to see or strong beliefs about lying, but they change their personalities to match what they think you would like. That's why you are tempted by both male and female devils. They're trying to find your preference. I also got a lot of this from the January exceptional story, Cricket, Anyone? Opposing the other comment here, I would suggest not using those terms at all. Sir and ma'am are highly outdated, and people under the age of 40 typically do not like them used to describe them. On the topic of gender nonconforming individuals, I can say as a trans woman who gets misgendered a lot that most people who are not in line with the traditional gender binary feel really uncomfortable when it comes to correcting random strangers on their pronouns. Gender nonconforming individuals typically have a lot of anxiety with how they are perceived, and if they are misgendered their typical reaction would be to get out of the situation as fast as possible rather than correct the individual and potentially make a scene. While the fact that you are asking this question makes it sound like you are a very welcoming and kind person towards the community, they do not know that. And even if they do, there could be a person nearby who is not. I recommend looking at this thread that talked about a similar topic, and it gives some suggestions for what to use in place of sir and ma'am. https://interpersonal.stackexchange.com/a/1119 Thank you for asking

As a trans woman myself, I know what you're going through. I went through a lot of it myself, even the thought "I can't do that, people don't just switch genders." On your fears that this is just a phase, I would not worry about that at all. It takes years for a trans person to get anything done that isn't irreversible. If you start slow with clothes and having people refer to you as female, and very slowly work towards the big things like hormones and surgery, then by the time you get to that point you'll have had years to think about this and decide if it is something you want. As for your parents, that is a tough one. Every parent is different, and you are the only one who is qualified to say how they might react because you know them better than anyone else. I would say that you should trust your gut, and if you truly think they already know and are waiting on you then you should tell them. However, before you do any of that I would make sure you have a plan to keep you safe. You should come out to a small collection of friends and adults who you trust before you talk to your parents, just to ensure you will have a safe place to turn in the event of anything bad happening. It'll also be great practice for when you come out to your parents. Best of luck

Maybe Marvin still has not confessed, so now it's Paul's job to get him to do that. Or, if you're like me and you plan to believe in the Paul=Care theory until the day you die, the game could be trying to get Paul to remember his life as Care so he can divulge where he was taken.

I'm not sure about the threat part, but I think it does explain why they were censored in the past, and how Paul recognized them. These things seem to be sort of secret family heirlooms, things only meant to be seen by people who are in the family already. That's how Paul immediately recognized it, and why he kind of freaked out when he saw them the first time. They were for the eyes of family members only, and yet they had somehow been recreated in some random game. As for why we get to see them now, maybe that is a threat? Saying how we the viewers, are too far in to turn back, and have become part of the family against our wills? Or it could be a nicer thing, meaning that we are trusted enough to see these things, and are considered a part of the family now It's weird

This is a commonly discussed theory, and it is one I personally love and look into a lot. One common explanation for Paul's seeming memory loss is that Paul has suppressed the horrible memories associated with being Care. Afterall, Care was kidnapped as a young child, and that certainly would have an adverse affect on anyone. But then why begin to believe that he and Care are a different person? Well, if Paul was Care at some point, it is likely that he is transgender. Some people say that maybe Marvin forced Care to become Paul, but I find that unlikely as Marvin seems focused on turning Care into the Windmill Girl, and forcing Care to be male seems counterintuitive to this goal, so I think Care's transition to Paul was a choice on her part. So after Paul transitioned, I think that the combined trauma of being kidnapped and both verbally abused and physically mutilated by his father lead to Paul forgetting his life as Care, and distancing himself from those events. For example, by pretending it all happened to a family member he never really met. (BTW: If this is true it would be a very toxic representation of trans peeps. Just wanted to poke in here and say that this is all fiction and not meant to be a real representation of what trans people go through. I am a trans woman myself, and understand the struggles) Anyway, the question the game seems to want answered is where was Care after she escaped from Martin. It says in 19 that Care "left her father's school" on one day and "arrived at home" two days later, but that no one knew where she was for the day in between. It's likely the game has been used to get a number of family members to admit to various things (Martin being the prime example), and right now it seems to be trying to get Paul to remember his life as Care to answer that question. Anyway, that was long, but that's my thoughts on it.
I'm not sure on why the question needs to be answered, but like it says in p17 "The family would like to know what happened" So maybe it's just curiosity?

Personally for me, I believe that Paul is Care after deciding to go through a gender transition rather than having something to do with the rebirthing process, like some other people think. I like this because it's more in the realm of reality(which I feel the majority of Petscop is), and because I'm trans so I like it :p. Either way, I think the change was likely to occur a couple years after Care escaped from Marvin and returned home. Going though such a traumatic event would likely prompt a lot of introspection on Care's part, and would likely lead to the realization that they wished to live as Paul.

WRITING.TITLE: I Think I Solved The Windmill Problem
WRITING.TEXT: Just like the title says. This theory does have some shortcomings, which I will explain at the bottom, but I think I'm onto something. Anyway, we all know the Windmill Problem. Marvin goes to see a windmill with his two female friends, one of them being his future wife, and the other being Lina, who will be disappearing and dying soon. Marvin and Lina play around inside the Windmill, as shown with the segment where Paul, playing as the Shadow-Monster-Man, goes into the Windmill, and plays with the mechanisms using a tool, while a female looking figure that represents Lina is nearby. My theory states that this is not showing Marvin doing anything sinister to Lina, but instead him tampering with the structural integrity of the Windmill itself. The scene as we know it is that Marvin, Lina, and Marvin's future wife are at the Windmill for whatever reason, and Rainer states that this was a bad idea. I believe this was a bad idea simply because the Windmill was old, and falling apart. The way Rainer phrased that saying did not imply that it was a bad idea for Lina to be with Marvin, simply that it was a bad idea to go to the Windmill at all, as if the Windmill itself was dangerous. For me, the only way a building can be dangerous is if it is structurally unsound. Anyway, the kids are playing at the Windmill and it is during this time that we get that scene of Marvin using the tool inside the Windmill. Then we get to the big question of the disappearing windmill. The scene as it is described is that Marvin and Lina are standing in front of the Windmill for one moment, and the next moment the only thing you can see is Marvin standing there, no Lina and no windmill. Whenever I do theories on Petscop, I like to base them in reality. I do not see Petscop as supernatural horror, I see it as a murder mystery. So while people are referencing different dimensions, and things of the sort, those don't do it for me. If the story goes in that direction, I'll accept it, but right now it feels like it isn't so I'm going to do my best time describe this incident as something that could happen in the real world. I believe that due to a combination of Martin's tampering, and the disrepair of the windmill, that the entire windmill collapsed. Viewing the collapse of an entire building would be extremely traumatizing, especially to a young child, and this could create the illusion in the minds of the viewer that the windmill simply disappeared. I believe this would have taken place shortly after Martin's tampering. He and Lina would have exited the windmill, Martin in front and Lina shortly behind. Lina's sister would have seen them leaving, and just as Lina was about to leave the windmill it would collapse. This would give the appearance that the windmill disappeared, and Lina with it. This would lead to the family labeling this event as a horrible tragedy, and only Martin would know that Lina's death was entirely his fault. Rainer would then do some research and find this out too, and confront Martin. TL:DR - Martin did something to compromise the integrity of the windmill, and it collapsed with Lina aside giving the affect of them both disappearing. Now, there are a number of problems with this theory. The first being that it appears that Lina actually died by getting hit by a car, due to what her tombstone says and the actions of the player character after discovering said tombstone. This not only throws a wrench into my theory, but also Rainer's original story where Lina disappeared with the windmill, and it is something we as a community need to figure out. The second being that Rainer seems to believe that Martin can find Lina's unmarked grave, implying that the family never found the body but Martin did, and he buried it himself. I do have a couple ways to explain this with my theory, but nothing super solid. One idea I've been throwing around is that Martin dug through the ruins of the windmill before help arrived in order to ensure there was no evidence that this was his fault. I see it as Martin's future wife running to get help while Martin says he is going to try and get Lina out. He gets any possible evidence towards his tampering, and finds Lina's body. For a reason I have yet to think of, he moves her body to another location, and later buries her. Why? Idk, and it's especially hard because we don't know how old Martin is right now. Like, if he's 8 then this is definitely not happening. But if he's a little older, say maybe close to his twenties? I can see him doing this. Anyway, the best reason for him doing that is because her body somehow provides evidence to his tampering. Or, if you want to go really dark with it all, perhaps he found Lina alive but badly injured, and since she saw him mess with the windmill he killed her so she wouldn't tell anyone, and hid her body so they wouldn't see that she was actually murdered. Anyway, I would say everything below the TL:DR is wild speculation, but the part before it actually holds some ground. I hope you like this theory, and I'd like to hear what you think.

I understand what you are saying, but I believe that you are completely wrong about this interpretation. In the spirit of professional debate I will go through each of your points and explain why I disagree with them. Family Values - I completely agree that one of the most important themes of this show is family values, that you must protect your family and support them. However, I do not believe that this is a purely conservative viewpoint. In fact, I believe that with the way it is portrayed in this show it is a more liberal one. One example would be Lady Margery being aware of her brother's love of men, and keeping this quiet from Joffrey, and even being willing to allow her husband Renly to be with her brother so the two could be happy. She loved her brother, and only wanted him to be happy. This acceptance for a family member despite their differences is not something that is in line with conservative ideology, and is instead something liberal movements try to encourage. Morality - When it comes to "alternative lifestyles" as you put it, I think you have missed a good portion of the show. When it comes to sexually open relationships, Oberyn Martell and Ellaria Sand are an example of a couple who has an alternative lifestyle and love each other very much. And while Oberyn did eventually die, he did so because of a mixture of his own hubris and his desire to avenge his sister. Or you could look at the large number of queer characters in the show. While they are still disliked I'm the primary high society, the average Joe doesn't care about hating them, and in places like Dorne or Highgarden they are accepted wholeheartedly. Again, something definitely not accepted by conservative ideology. And on the comparing of murdering children in the show to modern day abortions, I think that is not an equal comparison. In all the situations like that in the show, the mother is having the child taken forcibly from her, while an abortion is when the mother is willingly getting rid of a fetus. The reason those scenes are horrible are because the mother's are having their children taken from them despite their best efforts. Kind of like what modern conservative government is doing to the families of illegal aliens, although fortunately without the permanent nature of death. Political Correctness - I believe that this show actually does a great job of political correctness, and that is seen at the beginning of every episode. A warming about the content that is in the episode, and warnings like that are both needed for legal reasons but they are also a form of political correctness. That, and the show is a tragedy. My favorite saying is "Writing tragedy is not problematic." Basically, if you are writing a tragedy you will likely have scenes that would be culturally problematic in any other work, but if viewers are aware that the media they are consuming is a tragedy, then they know that the content within may be of a sensitive nature. Men and Women - Okay, I think this section is where you have come to misunderstand this show the most. Yes there are many male characters who protect their family, and yes there are many nurturing female characters. But there are just as many characters that are the opposite of this. I see that you mentioned Brienne, but she is only the most obvious character. Her entire character arc revolves around the fact that she has a lot of masculine traits. But outside of her we have Ygriette protecting Jon Snow when he first met the Wildlings, and even in the first assault on Castle Black. There is Arya, one of the main character who protects Gendry from the gold cloaks, gets him out of Harrenhal, and who made it her sole mission to protect her family by killing everyone who had ever wronged them. You have Cersei who was both nurturing to her children, but was just as much a protector to them. Or Catelyn Stark, who was nurturing to her children yes, but also fiercely protected them by trying to kidnap the man she believed to have harmed her children, and even until her death she fought to protect her children. On the flipside, you have Varys who was not a protector, but one who cared and loved those close to him. He did not actively protect Ross, but he was loving and caring towards her and treated her like family. In fact, he almost never took the protective role for anyone he cared for. He only loved them. I see you mention Sam in this section, and while he was definitely a protector, he was also a nurturing individual. He was extremely family oriented, and desired to help take care of Gilly's child and Gilly herself. Or Jorah Mormont who both wanted to protect Daenarys but who also cared for and nurtured her. As Dany needed less and less actual protection and more and more advice he switched roles, and supported her until his death. In short, Game of Thrones shows that men and women are the same. Both are capable of amazing things in all walks of life, and can have hopes and dreams outside of the extremely basic, two dimensional model of masculinity and femininity that you described in your post. Both men and women are simply people, and are capable of many different things. Walls work - I'm actually pretty sure that a big plot point of the last season is that walls don't always work? That aside, you said that this show puts the military in a positive light, and this is anything but the truth. You can look to Cersei talking to Sansa while they wait out Stannis' attack on King's Landing. She talks about how when a city is sacked, the attacking army rapes the women and kill children. Even Jorah agrees with this, saying how any men that follow Dany will wrongfully harm the people she invades. This is even further shown by Oberyn speaking of how his sister was raped and brutally murdered right after her children had been murdered in front of her as well. All of these actions were committed by men who were in the army, who you said believed in honor, but this is not honor. A common theme of GoT is that the men who make up armies are monsters. Daenarys was the Ultimate Democrat - I would actually say that if Dany resembled any modern political leader, I would compare her to Donald Trump before any democratic leader. Trump's entire campaign was "Make America Great Again" and you could say that Dany's belief system was quite similar. And you don't even have to look so hard to find news stories of former trump supporters who regret their decision because the policies he is setting are harming them personally. That and the fact that Trump does frequently threaten violence to those in his way or who critics criticize him. The system of government - I am going to neglect to talk on this point, as plenty of other people who are more knowledgeable on me in this topic have already explained in the comments why this section is wrong. The King - And finally, we have Bran as the king. A calm and dispassionate leader who values facts over emotions. I agree that these can be useful qualities for a leader, but when was the last time we had a conservative leader who acted in this manner? Looking at the current leader we have a man who will angrily rant at anyone who disagrees with him on a social media platform, who has tried to implement several policies that ended up falling due to him not thinking them through, and has personally insulted and called for violence against people in his congress that oppose him. As I said above, if Dany is to be compared to any modern day leader it is Trump. A hot-headed leader who does not consider the consequences of their actions before doing them, and causes their people to suffer because of it. Someone who is so obsessed with what they think is the perfect way to build their society that they harm anyone who stands in their way. I would personally compare Bran to president Obama. Not perfect by any regard, but someone willing to listen to their peers and think about their actions before doing them. A man who listens to the needs of the people, and does his best to slowly make the world better for everyone. That is all I have to say. I am sure this will be downvoted to Hell, but I couldn't stand such a blatant misinterpretation of one of my favorite shows.

Yeah, a lot of servers are like that. I would recommend either joining a server with people you know, or make your own. Another suggestion would be to look at some guides to get a better understanding of the game. DST has a pretty steep learning curve, and it's no fun of some random dude joins, dies in a stupid way, and then is now a constant sanity drain for everyone else. It's pretty hard to help people online in DST as you have to stop doing whatever you are doing to type instructions. Two channels I would recommend watching to get better is The Beard 777 and Volx. I hope you have a better experience next time you play

Pretty good for a beginner! I see that you took advantage of the potato thing set piece, very smart. One suggestion would be to move those grass and twigs closer to your alchemy machine before summer comes. You'll need an ice fling-o-matic by then, and you'll want all your combustibles away from your fire, although that is not a huge necessity. You'll need an ice box soon, so you'll need some gears. If you can find some clockwork knights around they can be pretty easy to kill without taking much damage, there are a large number of video guides that explain how to dodge their attacks. Bishops and rooks are a bit harder to kite, so for a new player I'd recommend avoiding them for now. And if you don't feel that comfortable fighting clockworks you can just go grave digging for a bit and hope you get lucky. I'd also hammer down that science machine for more materials. All around, you're doing pretty well. :)

Hero's down b is near useless. The reason a good chunk of the abilities it can use are so strong is because it is extremely difficult to find a time to use them. Hocus Pocus will never be used in competitive play because it has a chance to just kill you. Zoom is super useful, but will never be used to recover because why would you risk pulling a down b when your recovery is already pretty good? Kaklang is useful, but when will you ever use it? You can't just down b in someone's face because what if it's not there? Same for Kamikaze, Whack, Thwack, Kakrackle Slash, etc. They all require you to be near the opponent, and you can't just down b in an opponents face. Magic burst is a good edge guard option, but it is not a guarantee to even be pulled and if they miss or you get off halo quickly you can punish them while they are low on mp. The only good options are the "buffs" which are all reused abilities from other characters. Also bounce which I will admit might need to be nerfed a bit, but that is it. As for the crits, I see those as fine. It's just a slightly weaker Luigi misfire. Combine all of this with the fact that whenever you use down b all of the skills are in a random order, making muscle memory impossible, and that makes for a weak character a mid to high level. The reason hero is dominating right now is due to both match-up inexperience and poor play
Hocus Pocus will never be used in high level competitive play both because down b sucks in general, but also because hocus Pocus has a decent chance to severely harm you, if not kill you outright

First things first, you are going to need four separate Legend level Vestals. In my experience they are the only healers with the consistency needed to handle the dungeon, and in case you didn't already know, any hero who survives a trip to the Darkest Dungeon will refuse to go back, or you might be able to force them to go back at the cost of a heavy stress penalty depending on your difficulty setting. You will also always need a stress healer of any kind for each mission, a jester being preferred though the Houndmaster may be better for the third mission because that one is filled with beast enemies. Also, you should at least look up the maps of the dungeon before going in. No spoilers is cool, but without a map you'll wander into a lot of unnecessary fights and just die. Plague doctors are also super good because a lot of enemies in these dungeons deal heavy blight and bleed. The doctor can cure that easily. Also, a Hellion is nearly required for the third dungeon. No spoilers, but there is a lot of battles that need you to hit the fourth slot so iron swan is perfect. A few other notes, you never need shovels or keys in the dungeons so just save your money and not bother. Buy as much food as you can hold and use it liberally for healing. If you have The Color of Madness dlc I recommend grinding out the Mill district so you don't have to mess with hunger checks, but it's not too important. Don't bring anti venom on the first mission because no monsters there do blight, but pack all the bandages you can. Every mission following pack up with both bandages and anti venom.

In my opinion, the best districts are the Outcasts bonfire and the one that affects the Vestal/Crusader stun chance. They are helpful, but not super important. As for prot, most of the monsters are pretty average in that regard. The exception is the third mission, which has monsters with crazy high prot. Shield breakers would be amazing for that, and being able to hit every rank really good. Especially since a few enemies in the second mission and onwards are pretty good at shuffling your party around. Oh I almost forgot, after the second mission you no longer need the Talisman of the Flame trinket so don't waste a trinket slot on it after that's done
My fellow Americans

The blood curse isn't too bad, just another thing to juggle. It does slow you down a lot though. After a couple weeks all of your stress relief activities are weakened until you do a quest in the courtyard. The quest itself is fairly difficult, but not to hard if you know what to look out for. The real difficulty comes from after that where as time goes on monsters from the courtyard will start to spread into the other regions. This can cause the curse to spread through your whole roster. The only way to cure it is to fight a trio of extremely powerful bosses, the first of which is easily harder than any boss in the base game outside of the Darkest Dungeon stuff. In my opinion it is my favorite of the two DLCs. I just like hard boss fights. I'd say the main difference between the two is urgency. You are never forced to do anything for TCoM, and can procrastinate as long as you like. With CC you have to be on top of it or it will overwhelm you

The end goal to "Win" is to clear four quests in the Darkest Dungeon. The problem is that the Dungeon is one of the most hostile and dangerous places in the game so lower level heroes have no chance of surviving. So to progress you need to slowly do lower level quests to raise the level of your roster until you have a good collection of level 6 heroes and use them to clear the final Dungeons. Along the way you'll encounter bosses from each of the other regions. You don't need to kill these, but it is usually worth it for the money and trinkets.

It is a pretty harsh learning curve, abs usually the solution is to keep trying and learning. The biggest things I learned were these: Almost always remove/transform strikes and defends. Almost any card is better than a strike or defend And consider buying potions. If you know you're going to fight Hexaghost, consider buying a thorns potion. Is there a hallway fight in this act that you don't think you can beat with your current deck? Buy a smoke bomb in case you run into it. Finally, take the act you're in to prepare for the coming boss. Say you get to act three with a shiv deck and you suddenly see Time Eater. Now you have an entire act to do your best to adjust your deck to deal with it. Good luck! Keep climbing!

WRITING.TITLE: Best Neow Option For The Watcher?
WRITING.TEXT: Out of all the possible options Neow can give you, which one do you think helps the most in a Watcher run? I've recently started swapping my starter relic for a boss relic. Having four energy as the Watcher makes act one a breeze, and sets up nicely into future acts, and having four energy every turn is way better then a single miracle. But what do you think?

Well yes it is running the gamble, but now that they've downgraded a bunch of boss relics to common you're much more likely to get something good. And the problem with using your judgement to make a decision, the only info you have before you make the decision is the paths you could take and the boss of that floor, and the only choice that can be influenced by that is Neows Lament.

One reason it's so good is both the two cards with the randomizer. Every card you draw has a chance to be free, and now you get to draw more cards. But Snecko isn't amazing purely on its own, you need to build an entire deck around it. The three most important things about Snecko decks are card draw, discard, and energy gain. In the deck above, I have two powers that make me draw a card every time I change my stance. Since the two base stance changing cards are both two cost I have a higher chance of them being cheaper anyway, and whenever I exit calm I get more energy to play more cards that mess with my stance. Also I think someone did the math somewhere and Snecko is still worth taking in a deck with nothing but one and zero cost cards because of the card draw. Like, you will still end up playing more cards per turn on average. Anyway, Snecko is very powerful but it takes a lot of planning and getting used to, and sometimes you'll just have a horrible turn. I had a couple of those in this run, but that was followed up by a great turn next time to recover. Yes it's RNG, but it's RNG you can manipulate and exploit

WRITING.TITLE: One thing I hope to come in the future is.....
WRITING.TEXT: More bosses/elites. Before the Watcher was implemented, each of the three possible bosses/elites per floor connected to the three base characters. For example, Gremlin Nob relating to the Ironclad due to strength gain, the Sentries to the Defect due to being robots, and Lagavulin relating to Silent due to weakening opponents, I guess? (Admittedly that's the weakest connection) Anyway, with a new character that should mean new elites and bosses for each floor to match the Watcher. I really hope this is the case because seeing new enemies is so fun. That aside, one thing I want more than anything is a sort of bestiary for all the enemies in the game. It could have their names, health values, and maybe even their attack patterns. It could also show how many of them you've killed, and how many times they've killed you. But what I would want more than anything in this bestiary is a bit of flavor text for each enemy, like what they have on the relics. I always loved reading the flavor text on new relics, and this could add so many fun tidbits about recurring enemies and bosses. Anyway, this is just a fun thought I had

WRITING.TITLE: New Character Idea
WRITING.TEXT: As I #8217;m sure most of you are, I am extremely excited for the announcement of the next new character to join DST. The refreshes are always a welcome change, but new characters always mean so much more for the ever evolving meta. Wortox was a huge change, and while Wormwood was a familiar face he definitely brought a lot of interesting strategies with him. And now with the hype around the Woodie rework dying down, I #8217;ve started to turn my eyes towards what the next possible character could be. But before I get into my ideas and predictions, a little history. For those of you who did not know already, the first DLC character Wortox was actually in the base game of Don #8217;t Starve as an unfinished character. There were a number of unfinished characters left in the code of the base game, but Wortox stood out as he was in a state of surprising completion; having most of his sprites completed, his voice recorded, and even a few unique quotes written. He was cut from the game for unknown reasons, though I #8217;ll share my own theories on why he was cut later. Either way, he found his way into DST years later. This has lead a lot of people to look at other character that had been cut from the base game as possible future DLC options. Out of the handful of cut characters from the base game, there are only two that had the same level of completion Wortox had. The first being the Pyro character from TF2, a character which I #8217;m going to say is unlikely to be the next DLC character. It #8217;d be pretty funny if they were, but I #8217;m not betting on it. The last character who was nearly completed by inevitably cut, and the one I believe will be one of the next two DLC characters, was Wilton. Wilton was a skeleton character that used the same model as the failed survivors you find littered about the Constant. Like Wortox, he was fully modeled, had his voice sounds recorded, and even had a few unique quotes already written. And yet he was cut. Why? I believe Wilton was cut for the same reason as Wortox, he did not fit the theme of Don #8217;t Starve at the time. I believe Wortox was originally going to fill the role of Webber in the base game, a monster that is hated by pigs but gains unique benefits. However without a group of monsters to call his own, he likely was put aside in favor of the little spider boy. I believe Wilton, on the other hand, was going to fill the role of joke character that Wes would come to fill later. I believe that Wilton was eventually scrapped because he did not fit in well with the rest of the cast. Keep in mind that at the time the base game was released, and even into Reign of Giants, every single character lived in the real world and made their way to the Constant one way or another. It wasn #8217;t until Wilbur in Shipwrecked that we had a character who originated from the Constant, followed soon after by Wilba, Wormwood, and Wortox. So if Wilton was meant to be released alongside the main cast in place of Wes, it makes sense that Klei realized that a living skeleton would not fit well within the world they had created. Afterall, at that point in the series life there had been no signs of living skeletons. However, now that we are in DST, things are extremely different. Not only do we now have two characters who originated from the Constant, we also have a very important example of a reanimated skeleton, being the Ancient Fuelweaver. My concept for Wilton will revolve around making him closely related to the Ancient Fuelweaver itself. Firstly, I #8217;ll discuss what I think would be the intro animation for Wilton. Currently in terms of the story we are in a bit of a weird place with our characters. We saw them defeat the Fuelweaver and gain access to the ancient gateway, we saw them fight through the Forge and Gorge, and now they are suddenly back on the mainland again dealing with the new Lunar Island. Now it is possible that I missed something, but this just seems like a retcon of sorts. So with my idea I am going to make the assumption that they were planning on taking on the Fuelweaver, and then were distracted by a large chunk of the moon falling into the ocean. So the scene would start with Maxwell, Wilson, and Wickerbottom examining the Shadow Atrium, having it placed on top of an End Table. I #8217;m imagining that they are talking about what to do with the thing. As their conversation continues, their attention is drawn to the shore line and away from the Shadow Atrium. While they are distracted, Willow will approach the End Table and curiously pick up the shadow heart. She #8217;d walk over with it towards Wendy, showing it to her. Wendy would take it and look it over, and then draw a little heart in the air to show that she believes it is supposed to be a heart of some kind. Willow would look around, and notice a failed survivor lying nearby. She would point to it excitedly, and both she and Wendy would walk over towards it. As Willow leans down to place the Atrium in the chest cavity of the skeleton, Maxwell will finally notice what they are doing, and call out for them to stop. He will be too late as Willow places the Atrium in the chest cavity. What follows would be a similar animation to what the Fuelweaver does when it is summoned before rising to his feet as Wilton. I #8217;d also update his sprite in general so it isn #8217;t just a reused asset of the failed survivor, but there would be nightmare fuel particles in between the bones, much like the Ancient Fuelweaver. With the concept and the cinematic out of the way, now I #8217;ll go over his traits. Here is how they will be listed on his character. Has a burning hunger Is connected to unseen forces Is brittle Now for what may seem to be the craziest part of this character; his stats. His hunger rests at an insane 400 points. His health sits at a ridiculously small 5 points. And his sanity is hard capped at 0 points. I supposed I should explain why I chose this, and I #8217;ll start with the least ridiculous of the three; the hunger. With 400 hunger, Wilton has the highest hunger stat in the game. However, his hunger drain significantly faster, at around 100 points per day. This means that he can still go the longest without eating out of the whole roster, being able to go 4 whole days before his hunger hits zero. In addition to this, Wilton does not eat like a normal character. Much like Wortox, any food Wilton eats only fills him for half of its original value, and given his increased hunger drain this means he must turn towards other sources of food. And by far the best source of this food would be Nightmare Fuel. A single piece of Nightmare Fuel would be the equivalent of a normal character eating meatballs. Very efficient, even more so for reasons I #8217;ll get into later. In addition to filling him quite well, a single piece of Nightmare fuel will heal him for one point of health each time, and no other food is capable of healing him. We #8217;ll get more into the health side of things later. He can actually eat a lot of things. Living logs would be the equivalent of cooked meat, dark petals would be equal to butterfly wings, and anything that can be used to light a fire (logs, grass, twigs, boards, etc.) can be used with varying effectiveness. My idea is that his stomach functions a bit like the night light structure. It is a magical fire that must be kept burning. All this aside though, Nightmare Fuel will be your standard food. To help with this, Wilton will start with 4 nightmare fuel in his inventory, similar to how Wigfrid starts with meat. Also, more of as a funny easter egg and less of something you #8217;d actually do; but Wilton can eat a Shadow Atrium and if he does so his hunger will be maxed out, his health fully restored, and his hunger drain will stop entirely for one day. Just as something cool. Now to tackle the insanely low health. Before I go any further I should mention that any armor Wilton wears will not reduce the damage he takes at all. However, whenever he takes any form of damage, whether it be from picking a cactus all the way up to being struck directly by a meteor, that damage is immediately reduced to 1 point of damage. Now that I #8217;ve explained that, I #8217;m sure you can see how this character is playable. You basically get five total hits from any source before you die. I got the idea for this from the Bone Armor dropped by the Ancient Fuelweaver. It #8217;s armor that allows you to completely nullify any damage taken a set number of times before needing to be refueled by Nightmare Fuel. The idea is that Wilton is a skeleton, and he should die in one hit to anything. But because of the power of the Shadow Antrium, he is able to survive a set amount of hits before he needs to recharge. But Wilton is not permanently stuck at 5 health. Wilton has his own personal Magic recipe called Bone Reinforcement. It costs 4 boneshards, 2 pieces of Nightmare Fuel, and 25 points of hunger to craft, and gives Wilton an item that he can eat to gain 1 point of temporary HP up to a max of 20. These HP points would act like soul hearts in the Binding of Isaac, or armor in Enter the Gungeon. Once you get hit this HP is lost permanently and cannot be healed back up. These would primarily be used for boss fights, stacking a bunch in your inventory and eating them whenever you feel like you need to. As a side note, Wilton can still heal from a life giving amulet, he just heals one point at a time in exchange for a large chunk of hunger. Also eating Warly #8217;s nightmare pie won #8217;t kill him even though it should. I #8217;m just going to say that it maxes out his health because it has nightmare fuel in it. It should also be noted that when his hunger reaches zero he does not take tick damage like other characters, he just dies instantly. Even if he did take tick damage it would only take literally five seconds to kill him so its not that big of a change. In the same vein as that, Wilton does not suffer damage from overheating or freezing as this would kill him in seconds. Instead, if he is freezing he suffers a 50% movement speed penalty, the reasoning of this being that his bones are locking in place due to freezing. And if he overheats his hunger will begin to drain at double the speed until he cools down, bumping it to a massive 200 points per day. So temperature is not nearly as big a deal as it is on other characters, but it can still be your downfall if you aren #8217;t careful. Now for sanity, and I based this value off of the Bone Helm you can obtain from the Ancient Fuelweaver. This functions like a nightmare amulet, setting your sanity to zero, but has the bonus effect of making all nightmare creatures neutral towards you. It will have the same effect here. Nightmare creatures see Wilton as one of them, and will not attack him unless provoked. Also, I #8217;m going to say that Nightmare Creatures do not have a pack mentality, and attacking one will not provoke all the others. This allows for Wilton to always have access to his primary source of food in addition to being able to farm nightmare fuel much better than anyone else on the roster, and that would primarily be his function. Wilton is meant to make nightmare fuel farming easier, and if combined with a Wormwood that duo would be able to make countless Dark Swords for the team. Wilton would also make a great ruins rusher. He is unaffected by the constant sanity drain, will not be attacked by the swarms of nightmares, and is always surrounded by a good source of food in the form of Nightmare Fuel. Honestly, if Wilton were to exist in the game he would likely have the easiest time if he flat out based in the caves. As a smaller thing, Wilton would also be good for exploring the lunar island as he would constantly have 0 lunacy and would not be harassed by Gestalts. I #8217;m hoping they add positive effects of high lunacy in the future so that Wilton will be missing out on some things, but as of right now he would only have the advantage. As a side note, I #8217;m just going to say all obelisks will always be small for Wilton, I don #8217;t want him being trapped out of places because he can #8217;t raise his sanity. Also, just as a quality of life thing, I #8217;m going to say that shadow hands cannot harass Wilton. That would just be annoying. Anyway, that is the whole character! I really think this character would add a lot to the game. At the very least, it'd make a cool mod right?

Easily the easiest act 3 boss because he only scales when you do something. If you don't have a power heavy deck, you can just tank up against him. Pop a demon form, kill the cultists, and wait. Pop a couple dark orbs and wait, using one for each phase. Pop a Wish and gain Live Forever and wait. Really only the Silent struggles really hard against it as they don't have the sort of scaling as the other characters outside of poison, and the poison is lost on the death of the first phase. But even then it isn't too hard. Really, he is the Champ of Act Three. If you have any form of scaling you just wait out his first phase until you can one shot both of them

WRITING.TITLE: Just Lucky Challenge
WRITING.TEXT: Start playing as Cain Set every item to Lucky Foot. After that is done, give yourself the following Holy Tears Euthanasia Little Horn Money Equals Power The idea is that your luck will only grow bigger and bigger as time goes on, giving you more money drops to give you more damage with money equals power, more soul heart drops to help with health, and a higher chance to activate your extremely powerful tear effects. More tear effect items could be added to this, but I thought these would be strong enough to give you a chance without making this extremely easy.

WRITING.TITLE: What I Am Hoping For The Eventual Wes Rework
WRITING.TEXT: Ah Wes. The character everyone either does hate or is wrong and should hate. His rework will inevitably come at some point, my guess being that he will be the last character to be done. But what could they do for this character? To make him better would ruin his existence as a challenge character, and to make him harder would just make him even more despised. My thought for Wes is to make him difficult to survive on his own, but invaluable to those around him. I think he should keep his low stats, extra hunger drain, and weak damage. However, I would first give him a slight boost to speed, around equal to running on a road for all other characters. This will feed into his next trait which will be labeled: Hated by everyone This trait will cause all creatures capable of attacking to always be hostile towards Wes. Including pigs and Beefalos. This is a horrible downside, but it has its uses. As long as Wes is nearby, any mob will prioritize killing him, even if they are being attacked by another player. This could help in boss battles where a boss could be focused on Wes, who runs away, while other players kill a boss. This won't be foolproof, and for every 300 damage the enemy suffers from a source that isn't Wes they will lose their aggro on Wes and refocus on whatever last hit it. To regain aggro, Wes will have to hit the enemy to restart the cycle. Again, this trait will make solo survival with Wes a huge challenge, but be a useful tool to the group as a whole. His next trait will be Accustomed to dying This trait will make it so Wes does not suffer the penalty of being revived. He also will inflict half of the sanity penalty of being a ghost as compared to other characters. Not only that, but he will have a lot more things to do while he is a ghost. Whenever he haunts a creature it will go into a frenzy and try it's best to attack Wes' ghost for fifteen seconds, taking the aggro off of his teammates. And finally, I believe Wes should keep his balloons. They will function just like they do already, but will also draw the aggro of any enemies which will prioritize destroying the balloon over anything else, even Wes. This will mostly just help Wes survive on his own a little bit. Anyway, that's my idea. It is mostly just a joke, but I still think it would help Wes be a bit useful while still being a challenge character at heart
Definitely, and he is fun as a solo challenge, but he is so annoying in a multiplayer game. I tried to keep Wes as a fun challenge to play solo, but actually be helpful in a group.

Wortox already cannot interact with pigs and bunny men, and he is one of the best characters in the game. Plus, basing in a pig village is a bad idea anyway. I do agree that it would be hard if another player's tamed Beefalo attacked Wes, so maybe it could be changed so that Beefalo tamed by another player don't attack Wes. And besides, the point of this Wes is to be an insane challenge to tackle alone, but a reasonable one with friends.

While I do agree that a rework exactly as I suggested is not perfect, your addition does not seem to fit the theme of these reworks. Thus far each rework seems to strive to make each character a better team player. Winona gained catapults to assist in mob farming, Willow gained a huge tank summon and is able to better fuel fire, Woodie can explore and farm living logs, and Warly has his spices. While your suggestion does help the team, it does so without the Wes needing to do anything. All they have to do is stand nearby during a fight, whereas with my suggestion they must take an active approach. I would say that your suggested rework would make him much easier than mine. Also, if you are implying that Wes is a viable pick in a team composition in his current state, I don't think you know this game really well. As he stands, Wes is completely useless. Anything he can do can be achieved better by most other characters, and his miniscule stats make him utterly unnecessary for any team comp. Balloons are a fun novelty but utterly useless when compared to the options other characters can provide. With most servers only allowing six players at a time, and with character switching being a late game endeavor, a character slot is extremely valuable, and to take one of those limited spaces with a completely useless character is incredibly stupid unless you are doing something just for the sake of a challenge

gt;My idea fits that theme quite well while making compromises to both sides of the community. Wes like Warly would buff allies. Except unlike Warly, who has to work hard to get access to buffs, these would simply be always present. Therefore boring. gt;Wes is an able body with arms. He's just as viable as any other member of the cast. His potential may be lower, but he's just as viable. Except Wes isn't able bodied. He takes more swings from his weapons to kill anything, meaning more durability lost on weapons in any fight which is a waste of resources. The only person with comparable damage output is Wendy, and she has Abigail to help out. He also eats more food than most of the cast. And unlike the other hungry characters like Wolfgang or Wormwood, he eats more food without bringing a unique way to get said food to the table, like easier access to farming or a strong hunter. gt;No, some things he's equally tied for. "Unnecessary" does not mean useless or pointless. Wes is perfectly fine as filler, or combat roles. He's outclassed normally, but he's still viable. Literally any character is better at combat than Wes because he takes longer to kill enemies. And even if he isn't fighting, say he his farming or gathering, he still eats more food than anyone. gt;No, Wes isn't useless. What's useless is someone joining the server, and not choosing a character. An able body is an able body after-all. I would argue that with his extra hunger drain and damage dealt reduction it would be better for the whole team if no one joined than if a Wes joined. Wes is a challenge character, that is what he was in the base game and what he is in this game. And while a challenge character is fine in a solo experience, it is annoying for others when you are trying to survive together.
Again, Wes is a fun challenge in solo, but just an annoyance is cooperative play.

Yeah, and that's the point. Wes is a hard mode character on his own, but would be an invaluable tool for his allies. He could draw aggro while his friends kill a pig village, same for killing a few Beefalo. He could even make hunting Koalafants a little easier since they would chase him down instead of running away. In the end, to survive solo as this Wes would be an impressive feat, as all of his "perks" are purely a detriment to himself, but useful to everyone else
Sure he can, but as he participates he uses up more resources than he can contribute with both food and weapons
That's where I first got the idea, thanks for noticing :)

Of course you're able to survive with Wes, it's just harder. And it can be really annoying in a team where there is another team mate who is soaking up the resources you've already worked hard to collect
